Yes, there are medications that can help reduce anxiety symptoms by dampening the activity of the sympathetic nervous system.

One class of medications commonly used to treat anxiety disorders are benzodiazepines, such as diazepam (Valium) or lorazepam (Ativan). These medications work by increasing the activity of a neurotransmitter called gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which can help reduce the over-activity of the sympathetic nervous system.

Another class of medications commonly used to treat anxiety are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as sertraline (Zoloft) or fluoxetine (Prozac). These medications work by increasing the availability of the neurotransmitter serotonin in the brain, which can help regulate mood and reduce anxiety symptoms.

It is important to note that medication for anxiety should always be prescribed by a healthcare professional and used in conjunction with therapy and other lifestyle changes. Benzodiazepines, for example, can be habit-forming and have risk for dependence, while SSRIs can take several weeks to reach full effectiveness.

In summary, medication may be a useful tool for reducing anxiety symptoms by dampening the over-activity of the sympathetic nervous system. However, it should always be used in conjunction with therapy and other lifestyle changes, and under the guidance of a healthcare professional.
